XP is earned for collecting muffins and killing enemies that goes into a player level which awards you with skill points which can be spent on each individual creature. Respawns are super fast, controls are tight. The characters are adorable and silly (see Sumo Panda) All these features lend themselves to something familiar, easy to enter and super hard to put down. 												Muffin Knight is a game that looks catered towards toddlers, but is a perfect example of the idiom 'don't judge a book by its cover'. Despite looking very innocent and easy, 'Muffin Knight' is a surprisingly challenging game - especially if you're attempting to 5-star it. With a fantastic single-player and multiplayer co-op, Muffin Knight is a fast-paced game full of enjoyment, challenge and charm. Whilst the plot is simple and the graphics are subpar, Muffin Knight excels in its gameplay and can become dangerously addicting. The music is catchy, the controls are fantastically responsive and the added perks and upgrades really add to the game and genuinely make a difference, saving a very repetitive formula from going stale.My only complaints would be its lack of more settings, there isn't a lot of availability on how to customise the settings to best suit your PC, plus the menus are pretty awful if you plan to use a controller. Whilst I would highly recommend a controller for its movement flow and simplicity, I would suggest opting for a computer mouse when roaming through the menus.The randomisation for the characters can be frustrating, especially as some of the starters are incredibly weak until you upgrade them. Whilst upgrading doesn't take too long, to go from a strong character such as Cyclops or Grizzly, to a ridiculously weak character such as Monkey or Dragon, can really be annoying. Whilst mentioning characters, it is worthy ot note that the order of the unlockables seems very odd as well - whilst only a minor nitpick, I did feel very disappointed that the final unlockable was one of the worst.Overall, Muffin Knight is an incredibly fun and simplistic game to play. The added perks really help the game to feel different every time, and the challenge bar is at the perfect level for this type of genre. Whilst the plot is weak and some of the power-ups are far worse than others, due to the upgrades and points, you can quickly improve the weaker characters and make them some of the strongest. Muffin Knight is great fun with friends, but is also very enjoyable as a solo game - so go forth and find those muffins!Rating: 4/4

												In defense of this game, it works.  Which is really a big thing for a lot of low effort 2D platformers/shooters/whatever the indie studios churn out in shovelware by the tonne every year.The sound and graphics really function.The art style for a lot of the levels is thematically ripped from a strange combination of Mario and World of Warcraft.   Look, we're in Undercity! Look, we're in Zangarmarsh!  Gameplay is nothing new, the basic mechanic is present in literally over 1,000 Steam titles, you jump, you shoot, there's multiplayer jump and shoot.   Goombas totally inventive new enemies like sheep fall out of the sky and you have to kill them.It's hard to give this the thumbs down, because the developers achieved what they set out to do.   So, why the thumbs down?   Firstly - there's not enough technical customisability.  We can't even force the resolution.  The game handles okay today, but next year, the year after, it's going to fail to remain playable on newer systems.   This is a handicap enforced by the multiplatform system (because you know, console gamers and tablet gamers and PC gamers have so much in common). Secondly, well, what is this game contributing to anything?  I said earlier the developers achieved what they set out to do.   They succeeded in creating a game that fills no special niches, is derivative, and will certainly fail to be remembered alongside hundreds of other 2D indy platformers released every year hoping to be Super Meat Boy.  Was it a good idea to set out to do this? No, even if they succeeded.   This isn't worth the current price of $7 USD on Steam they're asking for.   Go play Super Mario Brothers on an emulator or something if you really have to do 2D platforming.

												First of all: I'm not going to show mercy on this game. So if that's something you wish to avoid, then here's your warning.TL;DR: It can be a fun experience, but that's most of it. That aside, it still remains a clone and lacks any love put into it from the developers. If you can get it for really cheap, check it out. Otherwise, stick with Super Crate Box, which is free.-----full review-----How to describe Muffin Knight... Well, I think saying it's Super Crate Box mixed with the graphics of Ducktales Remastered might just be the most accurate thing. But for the people who have never played Super Crate Box, allow me to ellaborate. The gameplay consists of you being put into some kind of arena, in which you have to gather enough Muffins to unlock the next stage, while being cautious of enemies who are trying to ruin your progress. Muffins also unlock new weapons when you obtained a select amount of them. And that is really all there is to it. I would say it's an innovative combat system, if they didn't straight out rip it off Super Crate Box. Some of the weapons do the EXACT same effect, but just having a dual pistol being replaced with an archer. This game is more on the child-friendly tour, so it replaced all weapons and enemies with weapons or mythological creatures.The story is very... vague. Protagonist finds a basket of Muffins and boom, he gets turned into a guy who can switch between weapons. Don't know what his goal is, but apparently he just needs to get his muffins back from some... dragonguy. NOTHING is explained in the game, except for the first part.At first it creates the illusion of difficult. You can't touch an enemy, or you're dead. Fortunately there are upgrades for that. You really have to make decisions about what to upgrade though. At first it might look easy to level up, but it becomes more of a grindfest at later levels. That is, if we exclude the extra modes this game has.Oh wait, did I say extra modes? Hahaha, aaah, how funny. Where do I begin...You start of the game in Knight Mode. Once you have beaten all the stages and defeated the final boss, you unlock a mode. And after you have finished that one, you unlock another. And another. And another. Would this be a problem? Not really, if it wasn't the EXACT same, just with increased difficulty. Why, in the name of Last Order, do this? Let us choose our dificulty, don't force it on us.And those reasons above form my biggest complaint with the game: It lacks love from the developpers. Like I said, I won't show mercy and I definitely won't here. They literally ripped off Super Crate Box, gave it a more child-friendly and HD design, and to avoid having a short game, let us repeat the game over and over again a total of 5 times. It's not even funny.If you can get this game for really cheap, go ahead. I definitely won't stop you. When I started this game, I did have a fun time. But over time, it just decreased. If you want to try out a game like this, get Super Crate Box.Note that I'm not trying to advertise Super Crate Box, but it's not only the same original game, but it's free too.

												Creating something unique is becoming a more and more difficult task in the world of smartphone gaming. There are so many games out there, and so many other people making new ones, that your brilliant idea has probably already been built and released.Equally, the huge swathe of clones and copycats that bloat the App Store make it even more refreshing when something does come along that's that little bit different. Muffin Knight, from Angry Mob Games, is one such breath of fresh air.As original as it is in the context of the App Store, however, it's important to note that Muffin Knight borrows heavily from Vlambeer's excellent Super Crate Box, which is also coming to iOS this month.Knights currantYou play a young boy who accidentally scatters a basket of magic muffins to the four corners of a cartoon-style fairytale world. Incensed by your actions, the fairy whose muffins they were turns you into a knight and sends you off on a quest to retrieve the arcane cakes.This takes the form of jumping around enclosed levels, killing scuttling pigs and other beasts and grabbing the deliciously enhanced buns. The twist is that every time you pick up a muffin you change class. You'll start as the eponymous Knight, but for the first few play throughs you'll swap between a mage, an archer, and a goblin as well.The characters all have different strengths and weaknesses, and as you play through the game you'll unlock new classes as well.While the original four are all quite similar ranged fighters, later in the game you'll have rainbow mine-pooping unicorns, fire-breathing dragons, and claw swiping bears at your disposal too.Confectionery crisisYou unlock new classes when you've picked up enough muffins, but you also gain XP for slaying enemies and gathering the small cakes. You can spend this XP on levelling up your characters, making them quicker and their attacks more potent.Of course, you're never sure which characters you're going to be in the game, so it's entirely possible to swap straight from a super-powered Knight to a one-starred kitten ninja in one muffin-fuelled swoop.All in all there are six levels to play through, all of which can be attacked multiple times, and 15 characters to unlock and upgrade. There's a multiplayer mode as well, which lets you connect with other iPhones over a local wi-fi network, to duke it out over who's the muffin-collecting monarch.Buns of zealMuffin Knight looks good, sounds good, and has a great, original idea at its core, but it's not all sweetness and light. The control system isn't perfect, with taps of the on-screen buttons sometimes not registering.It's pretty difficult as well, though even failure is rewarded with XP, meaning you'll be stronger the next time around. The lack of levels might put some off, but every play through is going to be different because your character changes are allocated entirely at random.These problems are mere niggles, though, and shouldn't dissuade you from playing this hugely enjoyable action-platformer. This is a leaping, blasting, clawing slice of fun that deserves to find a home on as many iOS devices as possible.

												Muffin Knight is a cute and simple throwback to older arcade-style games, where the goal is to dodge enemies and rack up points by collecting muffins.  Each time a muffin is collected, your character will lose his current attack ability and randomly select another from a decently long list of possibilities.  Scoring high earns points which can be used to upgrade the effectiveness of each job class.I found Muffin Knight pretty fun for a little while, but ultimately I cannot recommend the game.  At first, new classes and upgrades and levels come very quickly, but after a short while, it becomes a slog - each upgrade might cost three points, and you have to play the same level a dozen times just to earn one.  It seems as though the game was designed to be more addictive than fun or balanced - something that is not helped by the game's appearance, which looks and feels very much like it was a hastily done mobile port.The nail in the coffin for my enjoyment of the game, though, are the cheap deaths incurred from a broken enemy indication system.  Enemies drop onto the board from the sky.  Usually, there's a few frames of smoke as in indicator that enemies will soon be appearing.  However, that indicator seems really buggy - sometimes it appears in the wrong place, and sometimes it doesn't appear at all.  You'll grow used to enemies popping out of thin air directly on to you quite a bit.You might enjoy this title a bit, but unfortunately its an experience that wears thin after a while.

												Muffin Knight is a puzzle platformer based on the now infamous unity engine. There has been many assetflips based around this poor engine, however from time to time you get something that might be worth playing. This was my main objective as I embarked on a quest to see weather this would be a gem or another black mark upon the engines already unfavorable reputation.The short description of this game would be its like Suer Crate Box however instead of being free it cost you 7 of your hard earned euros. The fundamental game play is very basic and easy to get into. You are put in a very vertical 2d map and your objective is to collect as many muffins as you can while stopping the creatures from exiting the map at the bottom just like in Super Creat Box a free game. Unlike Super Crate Box Muffin Knight offers you a variety of differently themed levels that you progress trough be earing stars in each level.While you progress you earn points that you can spend in a skill tree kind of deal where you can also upgrade your health. By default you can only collide with one enemy unless you invest in health upgrades. The skills tree is not at all very interesting and could very easily been left out of the game completely as it doesn’t make the games any more enjoyable.Just like in Super Create Box a free game you unlock new and interesting characters as you progress all with different and sometimes interesting weapons. Such as deadly rainbow pop a black mark on Muffin Knight if you ask me. The dead memes are plentiful. All characters can be upgraded in the skill tree. Sadly the upgrades are not that interesting as it is the standard shoot faster deal more damage upgrades we see in most games.Now you might have noticed that I have been comparing this game to another game called Super Creat Box. To me it is obvious that this game was only made to grab a bit of money off of the success of the last mentioned game. The game is competent in what it tries to do however there is not enough innovation in Muffin Knight for me to recommend this game to you more than I would recommend you to take a look at Super Crate Box as it is a better game with less fluff and no dead memes. Oh yeah btw Super Creat Box Is also free.In conclusion. Go get Super Crate Box.If you want a score for Muffin Knight here it is. 0.5/Super Crate Box
